As we did with the National Crime Authority, as we did with the changes to the law of evidence, as we did with the Proceeds of Crime Bill, as we did with all of the enormous changes to the law in the last decade, it has been a Labor government that has done it in what is a relatively short space of time in the history of this country. I can say, and I can agree, it has often been with the support of the opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been a cooperative effort.

—On occasions, it has been cooperative; not always, but on occasions. This particular piece of legislation is being introduced with cooperation and support, and with the support of the lawyers of the parliament. It is interesting to look around and see that it is mostly lawyers who are standing in this debate and who are all supporting it so strongly. There are some who do not understand the law—we know that. Nevertheless, Mr Deputy Speaker, this is an important bill. Whilst it is at the moment Commonwealth law, what I find so pleasing about it is that the states are now cooperating with the Commonwealth through committees, and we hope—indeed, I will almost pray—that within a very short space of time criminal codification will occur across all the states so that there is a unified criminal law operating equally within each state.

PARA.TAB: I notice that the member for Tangney (Mr Williams) has left, but I can say that Victoria has not exactly run away from the process. You do not often find me praising Jeff Kennett—in fact, it is very rare, and I do not think I will even praise him now—but it is fair to point out that the Premier of Victoria has fully supported the process on codification now taking place. I understand Victoria has now joined the process of negotiation and consultation, so, hopefully, those changes will also occur in Victoria.

The difficulty that we have always faced in this country, as I said originally, is that the states have sovereign constitutional power and the Commonwealth has limited constitutional power. Hence, the only way we, at the federal level, can envisage a national parliament with a national set of laws is through the states. My plea today to the states will be: do not hesitate, do not wait, forget state pride, forget the antagonism which still exists between states, get behind the Commonwealth in this process and ensure that sooner, rather than later, we will have that codified law.

There are several aspects of the code, as it is now before the parliament, which are very noteworthy. The first, of course, is section 1.1, which should be noted because it states that the only offences—the only offences—against the laws of the Commonwealth are those offences created by or under the authority of this code or any other act. That is a very important statement. It is a statement which says that the parliament of Australia is the only body which has authority to create criminal offences. That sounds almost as though it need not be stated. But the reality is that, under the English common law system, judges have had the power to create new offences in the criminal area.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Mabo? Judges created Mabo.
—I am not at all criticising the High Court, which is an excellent court, with some fine judges on it, and I support it fully.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—The honourable member for Fisher will know that we are not discussing Mabo, we are discussing another bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —From a constitutional position, this is a very important statement. It is stressing the supremacy of parliament, which is something I wholly and fully support. It is an indication that the parliament is saying that judge-made law, rather than interpretation, is a thing of the past, and that the parliament is sovereign in terms of what is and is not a criminal offence or the elements of which will create a criminal offence.

PARA.TAB: I join the honourable member for Tangney in enjoying the fact that, finally, actus reus and mens rea will be cast from legal language. They are finally to be cast to the winds and lawyers will not have to sit back and pretend that they are Latin experts when they are not, and they will not have to spend hours practising how to say actus reus or mens rea. If you have a room full of lawyers, you will find 100 different pronunciations of the Latin words or the French-Norman words which so many lawyers love to use.

TALK.START.PARA: —None of them correct.

—You are probably right. They are often used in the wrong sense and there is the rest of the language which we love to use to pretend that we are knowledgeable in Latin. However, Latin is no longer a requirement for lawyers as it once it was. Another marvellous element of this criminal code is that, finally, we are talking about physical elements and mental elements, which are the two aspects where we once said actus reus and mens rea. Any reasonably intelligent person can pick up this code, read division 4 and understand what the parliament is saying about the law, and that was never possible in the past.

PARA.TAB: As far as division 2.3 is concerned, we are finally saying that there should be a uniform age from which criminal responsibility will flow. The code provides that it is 10 years of age, but currently each state has a different age. It is interesting in a number of ways. Honourable members will know that the current inquiry of the Joint Statutory Committee on the National Crime Authority concerns organised criminal paedophile activity. One of the things we are discussing at the moment, and which it is necessary to work out before we undergo the inquiries, is the question of what a child is. What is, at law, a child? When is an act paedophilic? When is an act not paedophilic? Is an act paedophilic when the child is prepubescent or when the child is postpubescent? There are areas which I had never thought of until we started this particular area of inquiry, and yet there may be, within this code provision, an area where we say that, in terms of paedophilic responsibility, a child under 10 is in the area we will look at.

That is for the committee to decide, but at least we finally may have a guide so that we can start to define, as a committee, what we are looking at when we talk about a paedophilic act. Currently the law defines sexual offences in terms of age. Even today, in one of the states, it is still a criminal offence for a male above the age of 21 years to have a sexual relationship with a woman above the age of 16 years and under the age of 18 years, even though it is not a criminal offence for a male above the age of 18 and below the age of 21 to have a sexual relationship with a female between the ages of 16 years and 18 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is that?

—In Victoria. It is the old offence of carnal knowledge, and it sits on the statute books in Victoria despite the fact that it has not been used for so long that people probably would have difficulty in finding out where it is. Again, in terms of some of these areas, we need to look at and to codify what we are talking about in terms of criminal and noncriminal sexual activity. It is all over the place between the states at the moment. The laws are old and they are often anachronistic. I recall that even when I was in the police force over 25 years ago the Victorian police did not charge under the 16 to 18 years of age carnal knowledge areas, even though they were often reported. This was primarily because it was so difficult to convict a person of a criminal offence in front of a jury when there was consent. Again, it is an area of codification which is required.

PARA.TAB: This is an area of law about which one can stand and talk for hours and it interests lawyers in particular. I know that Mr Deputy Speaker does not want me to talk for hours, but I confirm the fact, for those who are interested, that this is a very important piece of legislation. This legislation sets the scene for change throughout Australia: change which has been necessary for many years, but which has not been undertaken by the states. It requires a federal approach. It requires the parliament of the Commonwealth to instigate change and to work with the states in establishing—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Queensland Criminal Code came first.

—Queensland, with the Griffith legislation, has long been a codified state. Nevertheless, Queensland is not Australia. Queensland is just one little part of Australia. As a national parliament we are looking, I hope, at Australia rather than the anachronisms which we call states; because the sooner they go, the better. I support the legislation in its entirety. I commend the minister for the work he has done—and his staff, who I know have worked just as hard in this—and I look forward to Australia becoming a codified country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I always enjoy following my colleague the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland). I found what he said thought-provoking, although from the government's point of view perhaps a little self-serving in so far as he sought to give to the government full credit for the important steps which are being taken in these two pieces of legislation before the committee this morning, the Criminal Code Bill 1995 and the Crimes Amendment Bill 1995.

PARA.TAB: I think it is important to realise that there is in the community generally a desire that in a nation like Australia, as part of the many reforms that we should make to unify our laws as much as possible, the criminal law ought not to be exempted. In fact, my understanding is that the model criminal code was first a suggestion of one of the state or territory attorneys-general. We ought to be collectively congratulating ourselves as Australians on being prepared to bring forward and support two bills which I believe are major steps forward in unifying the criminal law in this nation and making it the same, as much as possible, throughout the country.

As has been mentioned, we are debating the Criminal Code Bill 1995 and the Crimes Amendment Bill 1995, and these two bills go hand in hand. It is very appropriate that in this place we should have a cognate debate, because the Crimes Amendment Bill 1995 in effect will include some provisions which will take effect until such time as the Criminal Code Bill comes into effect in about five years time.

When receiving advice on what was proposed in these two bills, as is usual the coalition consulted widely throughout the Australian community. We spoke to attorneys-general and shadow attorneys-general throughout the nation, to the Law Council, the New South Wales Criminal Lawyers Association, the Australian Federal Police and so on. I must say that there were no widespread major concerns in relation to the bills, although there were some aspects which, following a debate in the Senate, were referred to a Senate committee. That committee has recommended that the bills proceed, and thus we are not opposing what the government is seeking to do in this particular area.

The Criminal Code Bill 1995 concerns, as one would expect, the Commonwealth criminal law. The Commonwealth criminal law encompasses offences created by federal legislation and by regulations, and the principles of criminal responsibility applicable to those offences. To understand any of the current difficulties with our federal system it is important to look at the various state and territory approaches that we have. Various states and territories have different approaches to whether the law ought to be codified or whether there ought to be a common law approach.

In New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and the ACT the criminal law has been based on the common law approach. In those jurisdictions, while a significant proportion of offences are contained in acts and regulations many are based on non-legislative common law principles. On the other hand, the criminal law in Queensland, Western Australia, Tasmania and the Northern Territory is based on comprehensive codes, and in those jurisdictions there is no recourse to common law principles. It has been mentioned by my colleague the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams) that Sir Samuel Griffith drafted the criminal code in Queensland, and I believe that code has been followed in many other jurisdictions. It is interesting to see that the Commonwealth is following the Queensland lead in this area of codification of criminal law, although it has taken many years for this to occur.

In the early years following Federation, most criminal law was contained in the Crimes Act 1914. That has now changed and criminal offences are contained throughout every conceivable area of Commonwealth legislation. No doubt there is a great maze of confusion because, to ascertain what are Commonwealth criminal offences, one has to go to the government printer and look through almost every statute. As the concept of Australia as a nation has grown, the Commonwealth has brought in many additions to the criminal law in areas such as heritage, the environment and so many other areas which were not envisaged as being suitable for criminal law in those early years.

We have a situation where a person could be charged with a Commonwealth offence in a particular state or federal court and, when this occurs, principles of criminal responsibility need to be applied in determining a person's guilt or innocence. Believe it or not, at the present time

SPEECH.PARA: principles relating to Commonwealth offences are disparate and unsatisfactory. If the offence is contained in the Crimes Act 1914, common law principles apply. For the remainder and majority of Commonwealth offences, the Judiciary Act 1903 provides that the relevant state or territory laws apply.

PARA.TAB: This has created a substantial degree of confusion because it could mean that, if a person is charged in one part of the country with a certain offence, then the prosecution would proceed on the basis of the laws and principles of that particular state or territory and, if the offence occurs and the matter proceeds in another part of the country, then a different law could apply. There are major problems of equity when this happens because the different principles which apply in different parts of the country could well impact substantially on the outcome. Most reasonable people would say, if a person is charged with an offence in Australia, that it is appropriate that the rules governing the prosecution should be the same regardless of whether the trial occurs in Queensland, New South Wales or any other part of the nation.
Criminal law is a very important area of the law. It is interesting that Jeremy Bentham, when speaking of how the English common law was made at the time, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Just as a man makes law for his dog. When your dog does anything you want to break him of, you wait till he does it, and then you beat him for it.

While the common law has come a long way since then and the principles are much more certain, one thing that is important, as was indicated by prior speakers, is that when you do have a codified criminal law you have a very great degree of certainty. That is very important in the Australia of 1995. It is important to know what the law is and it is important that, wherever possible, the law should be the same throughout the country as far as Commonwealth offences are concerned.

PARA.TAB: This matter was reviewed by Sir Harry Gibbs and his committee. The review of commonwealth criminal law recommended that there should be general principles for criminal responsibility for Commonwealth law. That report was brought down in 1990. It is interesting that this was not totally a Commonwealth initiative. State and territory governments were very keen to take up the challenge and, as I said previously, it was a state or a territory attorney-general who first suggested a model criminal code. In fact, that gentleman was the Hon. Daryl Manzie, who was then the Northern Territory Attorney-General. He suggested that the issue be placed on the agenda of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. Out of that the Criminal Law Officers Committee was established and that has been renamed the Model Criminal Code Officers Committee. This committee has worked long and hard and the concept of a model criminal code, I believe, will become reality. It is very interesting to see that all states and territories are interested, wherever possible, in working together to ensure that this model Criminal Code becomes a reality.

The Criminal Code Bill represents the first part of the implementation of the recommendations of the Gibbs review and, because there are so many things that have to be changed and so many areas right across the law, the implementation will take five years. The government has decided that, in order to achieve consistency while the reform process goes on, there should be an interim position whereby common law principles are applicable to all Commonwealth offences. That requires an amendment to the Commonwealth Crimes Act and that amendment is dealt with in the contemporaneous Commonwealth Crimes Act Amendment Bill 1994 which is being debated in a cognate way with the principal piece of legislation we are talking about.

Ultimately, the reform agenda is wider than the attempt to codify Commonwealth criminal law. Of course, the aim is to achieve uniformity across all jurisdictions of criminal law principles by the year 2001. Most importantly, that goal has been endorsed by SCAG, the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. I think that is a major step forward and I understand that a draft model criminal code, first suggested by the Northern Territory Attorney-General, will be available by 1998.

The bill actually sets out principles of criminal responsibility which will apply within five years to all Commonwealth offences. The principles are contained in chapter 2 of the code. The five-year delay is necessary because there are a large number of amendments that have to be made across the range of Commonwealth legislation. That is because the offences are drafted on the basis of the principles that may apply. The delay is also a result of the plan to incorporate, with appropriate redrafts, the offences contained in the Crimes Act 1914 into the code. It is planned that those offences will be moved into the criminal code in 1995.

The act will be proclaimed and will apply in relation to offences within the code. The code will apply to other Commonwealth offences not later than five years after the date on which the act receives royal assent. The bill is being introduced to put a firm legislative base on the statute book. This will indicate faith with the states and territories and will indicate in a very compelling and certain way that the Commonwealth is committed to the development of a model criminal code. I am pleased that all parties in the parliament support this very welcome development. At last we are getting the cooperation in this area that has eluded us for quite some time.

Chapter 1 of the code deals with codification itself. At present, all the chapter provides is that the only offences against the Commonwealth are those created by the code or by any other Commonwealth act. In other words, when the code comes into force there will be no common law Commonwealth criminal law. The principles contained in chapter 2 are a combination of the elements of the common law jurisdictions and the code jurisdictions. As noted in the second reading speech, on the one hand the code contains subjective fault based principles of criminal responsibility which reflect the approach of the common law jurisdictions while, on the other hand, it has provisions such as those relating to intoxication, which are closer to the approach of the code jurisdictions.

Chapter 2 of the code is divided into parts 2.1 to 2.6 inclusive. Part 2.1 of the code outlines the purpose and application of the chapter, which is to codify the general principles of criminal responsibility. Part 2.2 deals with the elements of an offence. It provides that an offence consists of physical elements and fault elements which provide the traditional analytical bases of offences, known as actus reus and mens rea, respectively. Characteristics of the physical elements and fault elements are described in detail in the remainder of part 2.2.

The code follows the common law approach in specifying subjective fault elements. The second reading speech also indicates that this was the preferred approach in the vast majority of submissions received and there is a consistency with the US model penal code, the English draft code, the Canadian draft code and, of course, the Gibbs committee recommendations.

Part 2.3 contains circumstances in which there is no criminal responsibility. It deals with criminal responsibility of minors, mental impairment, intoxication, mistake of fact, mistake of law, claim of right, intervening conduct, duress, emergency, and self-defence. The mental impairment provisions follow what is known as the McNaghten test. That test and the relevant provisions provide that a person is not criminally responsible for an offence if a person was suffering from a mental impairment such that the person did not know the nature and quality of the conduct or did not know that the conduct was wrong or was unable to control the conduct.

Particularly noteworthy are the comments in relation to intoxication. Under the provisions, voluntary intoxication cannot be taken into account in determining whether conduct was voluntary or whether fault elements of an offence element of basic intent existed.

It is actually quite interesting because there has been a lot of controversy in relation to this particular area. On balance, the government has come up with one position. Not everyone will agree with the government but I do accept that the government has come to this decision honestly. I have some concerns about it and I know that a number of other people do also. Be that as it may, the coalition is not opposing this particular proposal.

The government has actually stated that the approach taken in the bill was consistent with that endorsed by SCAG. Part 2.4 deals with extensions of criminal responsibility. It contains provisions dealing with attempt, complicity and common purpose, innocent agency, incitement and conspiracy. The bill also makes amendments to the current conspiracy laws to take into account judicial and other criticisms of abuses of conspiracy laws. The provision imposes limits on the situations where conspiracy applies. A lot of the time it seems that people are charged with conspiracy when the Crown cannot dredge up any other offence. I think that what the government is suggesting here is a positive step.

Part 2.5 deals with corporate criminal responsibility. There were some concerns with what the government was suggesting here but there has been a recommendation that this matter proceed as part of the bill. Part 2.6 codifies established principles dealing with proof of criminal responsibility and the respective burdens of proof that must be discharged. The government has decided that certain areas cannot wait for the five years and that is understandable. It has decided that the age of criminal responsibility must be determined and put into effect now. The law of attempt must be clarified and also the law relating to conspiracy.

Provisions mirroring those in the bill have been included in the Crimes Amendment Bill 1994, which is intended, as I said earlier, to take effect relatively soon. When the Criminal Code Bill enters into force, the Crimes Amendment Bill 1994 will be repealed. The government is bringing in the cognate bill, the Crimes Amendment Bill, to cover the loopholes until the principal piece of legislation becomes law.

The interim measure could be criticised by some saying that really it is a stopgap measure. I think it is important that, given the matters to be covered by the Crimes Amendment Bill, these matters are brought into law now. The coalition is certainly not opposing what the government is suggesting. The matters included in the Crimes Amendment Bill 1994 include the age of criminal responsibility which, as the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) said, will standardise the current situation so that persons under 10 years cannot be liable for offences against Commonwealth law. Concerning the law of attempt, the provisions require that the conduct said to constitute the attempt must be more than merely preparatory to the commission of the offence. The provisions allow a conviction even where committing the offence attempted is impossible. With respect to the law relating to conspiracy, the provision aims to reduce abuse of conspiracy charges. The provisions only apply where the offence to which they relate has a penalty of more than 12 months imprisonment or a fine of more than $20,000. Proceedings may only be commenced with the consent of the Director of Public Prosecutions.

So we have a situation where we have two bills before the Committee today. These bills are the product of a long period of consultation, a long period of cooperation between people at this level of government and those representing the states and the territories. I commend the minister on this particular approach. I commend the government and all those who have participated in the discussions until now. The law has been complicated. There have been problems. We have, quite often, continued to operate as though we are six or seven different countries and not a nation. I do want to reject absolutely the suggestion made by the honourable member for McEwen that the states should be abolished. I believe in the federal system. I believe the states perform a very worthwhile function. It ought to be remembered that a federal system is a guarantee of decentralisation of power. When we have a decentralisation of power, it is fairly clear that we will not have a concentration of authority in too few hands.

If we abolished the states and we gave all power to the Commonwealth parliament and, indeed, to the Prime Minister, that would be a very retrograde step from the point of view of Australian democracy. I therefore support the federal system of government, as does the coalition, but that does not mean that we will not work and cooperate with all other levels of government and encourage cooperation to ensure that, wherever possible, we are able to standardise laws and procedures throughout Australia. Quite often the different laws and the different procedures we have had in different parts of the country have ensured that inequities and unfairnesses have occurred, and no-one would support that.

The legislation before the committee today is important legislation. It is a positive step forward. It indicates the Commonwealth's commitment to this cooperative approach. I commend the minister, I commend the government, but I commend also all of the state and territory governments which have been part of this very important process, which I believe will be of immense benefit to our nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I will make a couple of short remarks to conclude this debate. Before I turn to some more general comments in closing, I take this moment to put on record particular thanks for the work of David Neal, who chaired the Model Criminal Code Officers Committee for some time and then proceeded to work as a consultant in the area. David Neal has just recently had a motor vehicle accident which has caused him quite severe injuries. I am sure that all members of this committee would wish him well in his recovery and hope that the sterling work he has done, which has been so widely commended in the debate, continues. We might also recognise the work being done by those in the department that have been supporting the process. They have been entirely committed to it. We have set a fairly tight timetable in going to the year 2001—the pressure is really quite on them—and they have risen to the occasion very well.

PARA.TAB: I will make a couple of remarks about what has been said in this debate. Firstly, I thank the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock), the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams) and the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper), from the opposition parties, who have spoken. I thank them for their commendation of these measures and the generosity of their remarks regarding the way in which this process has proceeded.

I thank my colleague the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham) for the vigorous way in which he debates with me and others within government in relation to issues of principle. His is always a vital voice to be listened to in these areas and I note particularly his warning that, as we move down this process, we should avoid following models which have commended themselves in the United States and in Europe but which appear not to be appropriate for us to follow. I note also his concern that we should not allow ourselves as parliamentarians to be drawn into knee-jerk responses to immediate pressures that come from time to time, but should rather look at this as a constructive and consultative process that needs to bear in mind the whole range of issues, including those coming from those concerned with law enforcement, those concerned with civil liberties and those concerned with the community as a whole.

As to my colleague the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland), I thank him for his generous remarks. I too am pleased that Victoria now is settled into the process of reform. The comments by the Victorian Premier I welcome very much, in his commitment in joining with other premiers towards uniform criminal legislation.

I close by saying that the thing that really impresses me about the development of the Criminal Code Bill is the way in which all those involved, whether they be state or territory officials or the parties in this parliament, have worked well towards achieving agreement on principled and workable sets of laws suitable for adoption across Australia. I think it is a fitting credit to this parliament that it be the first to enact general principles of criminal responsibility, as an expression of confidence in the aim of uniformity, and I look forward to other governments doing likewise.

This bill was scrutinised in detail by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, which includes the opposition and Democrats spokespersons on the Attorney-General's portfolios. I wish to personally thank Senator Vanstone and Senator Spindler for the spirit in which they approached the bill. I know that they have made an important contribution towards the development of worthwhile, progressive and uniform criminal laws for Australia. I might note that in debate each raised some specific matters on which they have sought further advice, and I will undertake that in due course my department will respond to the specifics that they have raised.

I believe, however, that the contributions from those who have spoken in this debate have all shown vision. The same can be said for the support that has come for the criminal code from the highest levels of government. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and each Premier and Chief Minister have committed themselves to the ongoing development of the model criminal code. That is very important since the project is long-term and is aiming for completion in every jurisdiction by the year 2001. I thank all the members of the House who have participated.
