SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay The Hon E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LINDSAY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Archives Amendment Bill will make amendments of a minor policy nature to the Archives Act 1983. The Australian Archives plays an important role in ensuring that the history of government in Australia is preserved and is available for access by future generations of Australians. These amendments are intended to clarify the application of the Archives Act to two types of records, namely the records of government business enterprises and other commercialised bodies and the records of the national witness protection program.

PARA.TAB: The proposed amendments will not have any significant financial impact. However, the amendments relating to government business enterprises will result in indirect savings through improved efficiency in the process associated with the commercialisation, incorporation and sale of government bodies.

The first category of amendments concerns the application of the Archives Act to government business enterprises. In the last few years, the Commonwealth has been reviewing the structure and operations of government business enterprises. As a result, a number of these bodies have been commercialised, incorporated or privatised in order to improve the efficiency of their operations.

Unfortunately, the method used to incorporate or privatise these bodies in the last few years has resulted in problems for the Australian Archives. The first is that legislation used to privatise or corporatise the government enterprise has, on several occasions, had the effect that the body was no longer subject to the Archives Act. The second problem is that a particular legislative process used to incorporate bodies also had the effect of removing all the pre-incorporation records of the body from the operation of the Archives Act. As a result of this process, the Australian Archives has lost control of the pre-incorporation records of bodies such as the Commonwealth Bank, the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, the International Wool Commission and the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation.

The amendments concerning government business enterprises are intended to prevent the inadvertent removal of records from the operation of the Archives Act as a consequence of a change in structure of certain bodies. To this end, the bill provides for:

SPEECH.PARA: .bodies that either are established for a public purpose or subject to Commonwealth control to remain subject to the Archives Act unless specifically excluded from the operation of the act; and

.the prior records of bodies which are subsequently removed from the application of the Archives Act to also remain subject to the act unless specifically excluded from its application. These amendments will preserve established statutory rights of access to records of national significance or public interest.

It should be recognised that the bill will not prevent the transfer of Commonwealth records where the government decides this is necessary. The amendments provide for the government to preclude the application of the Archives Act to commercial government bodies, either by means of the legislation relating to the incorporation or sale of the body or by an amendment to the regulations to the Archives Act. The bill will not apply to bodies that were excluded from the application of the Archives Act prior to the commencement of these amendments.

PARA.TAB: The second category of amendments concerns the application of the Archives Act to the records of the national witness protection program. Earlier this year the government enacted the National Witness Protection Act 1994. This act provides a legislative basis for a program run by the Australian Federal Police which is designed to facilitate the provision of high-level witness protection, including the issuing of alternative identity documents for protected witnesses.
This bill makes special provision for access to and custody of records of the national witness protection program. The bill:

SPEECH.PARA: .permits the Australian Federal Police to retain custody of certain sensitive documents relating to the national witness protection program, rather than requiring those records to be transferred to the Australian Archives;
.ensures that certain highly sensitive documents relating to the national witness protection program are exempted from public disclosure under the Archives Act; and

.makes specific provision for the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, or a staff member associated with the national witness protection program, to provide documents and/or evidence to a private hearing of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Archives Amendment Bill seeks to ensure that bodies established for a public purpose or under Commonwealth control, such as government business enterprises, remain subject to the Archives Act 1983 after a change in their structure, and that legislation in relation to the national witness protection program is clarified. These proposed amendments are not anticipated to have any significant financial impact. In fact, the government has claimed that the amendments relating to government business enterprises will result in minor savings through improved efficiency in the process associated with the commercialisation, incorporation and sale of government bodies.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Archives is responsible for the management of Commonwealth records, including the transfer of ownership or custody of such records. There is currently no legislation in place which prevents bodies established for public purposes, such as government business enterprises which have been commercialised, incorporated or privatised, from inadvertently or otherwise removing their pre-incorporation records from the Archives. As a result, the Archives has already relinquished control of the pre-incorporation records of such bodies as the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, the International Wool Commission and the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation.

The amendments which the government is proposing will ensure that all records in relation to bodies such as these and government business enterprises will be subject to the Archives Act 1983. This means that the Archives will have control over the pre-incorporation records of bodies which are subsequently removed from the application of the Archives Act as a result of structural changes, unless the legislation associated with the change, or an amendment to the Archives Regulations, specifically exclude the body. The government must, in other words, consciously decide whether or not records should stay in the Archives or be transferred to the new body. The coalition does not oppose these amendments.

The bill also deals with the records of the national witness protection program. The proposed amendments will clarify the current legislation concerning the protection of witnesses or participants in the national witness protection program. This will be achieved by identifying the circumstances in which records associated with the program can be exempted from being transferred to Archives and by protecting certain material from being publicly disclosed.

The Australian Federal Police will be able to retain sensitive documents relating to the program, and the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police or a staff member associated with the program will be permitted to provide documents and/or evidence to a private hearing of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
These amendments will strengthen the protection afforded by current legislation and, again, the coalition does not oppose them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak firstly on the amendments relating to the records of government business enterprises. The Australian Archives has a statutory responsibility to ensure that Commonwealth records of value for historical research or which document rights and entitlements of individual citizens are preserved for future generations.

PARA.TAB: The present amendments to the Archives Act 1983 address a problem which has become evident in recent years with the corporatisation and privatisation of Commonwealth functions. There have been a number of instances in which valuable Commonwealth records have been transferred or sold with government business enterprises. Although this was not necessarily the intention, it occurred because of the form of the legislation authorising the sales. In consequence, there was no longer a public right of access to the records once they reached the age of 30 years and, hence, the new owners had the right to destroy them if they saw fit. The Archives has naturally been concerned for a number of years to rectify this situation to ensure that valuable records are preserved.

In some cases, records of privatised enterprises are of no further interest to the Commonwealth or the public, and it is appropriate for them to be transferred to the new owner. However, as has been mentioned in earlier speeches, there are other cases—for example, the Commonwealth Bank, the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation, Australian Airlines and the Australian National Line—where the records include important historical material.

The only existing remedies for this problem are: to seek to have provisions for retention of the records included in the legislation authorising the incorporation or sale of the enterprise; to bring the records back into the coverage of the act by regulation; and to induce the new owner to deposit the older records with the Australian Archives' corporate archives service. All three remedies are uncertain and time consuming.

The amendments provide that, if a Commonwealth enterprise is sold, the records which are created up to the time of sale will continue to be subject to the Archives Act 1983, unless there is specific provision for their removal either in the legislation authorising the sale or in a regulation under the act. The amendments are not intended to keep all such records within the act, but merely to ensure that the issue of their appropriate disposition is consciously addressed as part of the sale process.

The second item I wish to discuss is the amendments relating to the national witness protection program. The amendments are intended to strengthen the protection of information which might lead to the identification of protected witnesses. They are consequential to the passage of the Witness Protection Act 1994.

The amendment to section 29 permits the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police to determine, without the need to seek concurrence of the Director-General of the Australian Archives, that records may be withheld from transfer to the Archives if their release might endanger the safety of an actual or potential protected witness. All records of the security and intelligence agencies already have a similar protection.

The amendment to section 33 confirms that the exemption category covering confidential sources of information in relation to the enforcement or administration of the law extends to a person who has provided confidential information to the National Crime Authority or the Australian Federal Police or who has been included in the national witness protection program.

The amendments do not remove the statutory right of members of the public to seek access under the Archives Act 1983 to records relating to protected witnesses once the records reach the age of 30 years, regardless of whether the records are by then in the custody of the Archives or the Australian Federal Police. Nor do they prevent members of the public from applying to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for a review of the decision to exempt such records from public access.

I now turn from the specific amendments to say something about the Australian Archives. Although 1994 marked the 50th anniversary of the appointment of the first Commonwealth archivist, throughout most of that period the Archives has been very much an organisation in the background. An archives act was developed during the 1970s but was not passed by this parliament until 1983.

In recent years, the Australian Archives has sought to put greater emphasis on its public role—its role in relation to all Australians—and to make more Australians aware of what it has to offer. It is thus assuming its rightful place as not only an integral part of government administration, but one of the significant cultural institutions of our country. The Advisory Council on Australian Archives, of which I am a member, has actively encouraged the Archives to be more outgoing and to make its achievements and collections better known.

The role of a national government archives is not always apparent, yet it is one of the essential supporting pillars of any democracy. The Australian Archives contributes to the maintenance and understanding of political, social and cultural values in Australia. It does this in three very clear ways: it promotes the role of records as evidence in supporting the role of law; it supports the effectiveness and accountability of government administration; and it preserves documentation about the interaction between the people of Australia and their governments.

The history of the Australian Archives has been one of significant achievement. The Archives has devised a unique system for the intellectual quality of records. This system has become the de facto standard in Australia and it is copied and emulated widely. It has set new standards in the management of access to government records. These standards balance the public's right to know and the competing demand for protection from unreasonable disclosure of personal affairs.

In size and scale, the Australian Archives is the dominant archival institution in Australia. It is established in each state and the Northern Territory, as well as in Canberra, and its collections are truly distributed. It holds over 200,000 shelf metres of records of enduring value, documenting the archives of government and people. Almost every subject imaginable is represented in its collections, which are a little known treasure trove of information on our nation's development.

Something of the flavour of what I want to convey about the Archives was captured in an editorial in the Canberra Times earlier this year. It described the Archives as `one of the great treasure houses of Australian history and culture'. It also noted that for most of its 50-year history the treasure has been sadly underdeveloped, under-resourced and underexploited, even by government and the bureaucracy, let alone by the public. The editorial continued:

SPEECH.PARA: The Archives holds most of the constitutional documents which are the national birth certificates; just as significantly its records of public administration and policy development tell not only of the development of the nation and how Australia's politicians and public servants handled their public trusts, but also the stories of millions of Australians: our Aborigines, our immigrants, our soldiers, our industries and our agriculture, the development of communities, particularly Canberra, and the way Australia and Australians saw the world and changing times.
In recent years, the Archives has had some notable achievements which I believe should be mentioned.

PARA.TAB: One such achievement concerns the type of paper which is used when records are being created. Building good quality paper into records of likely long-term value saves preservation dollars. The adage about prevention being better than cure certainly applies when the size of the Australian Archives' existing preservation challenge is understood—those 200,000 metres of records of enduring value amount to over 1,100 million individual documents. Building recycled paper into files of short-term importance also makes good sense.

The Australian Archives has taken on the issue of paper quality and has taken notice of the increasing concern in the community about the environment and the growth of interest in recycled papers. It has used this concern to promote the development of archival quality paper manufactured through processes which use industrial cotton waste rather than virgin pulp. Through a joint venture with Australian Paper, Visyboard and Unistat, the Australian Archives has ensured the manufacture and marketing of a range of paper products and storage containers at low cost.

The availability of these Australian made products will allow all cultural institutions to have access to high quality materials to improve the preservation of Australia's cultural heritage. On the other side of the coin, in order to promote the use of recycled papers in appropriate cases, the Archives has developed and published guidelines for the use of papers. Those guidelines set out for the user situations where it is appropriate to use recycled papers and those where archival quality papers should be used.

The Australian Archives has also recognised the challenges presented by the development of electronic records, and it certainly does not underestimate these challenges. They were encapsulated in an article in the January issue of Scientific American written by Jeff Rothenberg, a computer scientist with Rand Corporation. Rothenberg began the article with the following scenario:

SPEECH.PARA: The year is 2045, any my grandchildren (as yet unborn) are exploring the attic of my house (as yet unbought). They find a letter dated 1995 and a CD-ROM. The letter says the disk contains a document that provides the key to obtaining my fortune (as yet unearthed). My grandchildren are understandably excited, but they have never before seen a CD—except in old movies. Even if they can find a suitable disk drive, how will they run the software necessary to interpret what is on the disk? How can they read my obsolete digital document?
Of course, electronic records pose problems not only for individuals but also for governments, and they are with us now, regardless of what 2045 will bring.

PARA.TAB: In this rapidly developing area of communication and technology, there are no hard and fast rules. The Archives has recognised, however, that guidance and advice is necessary even in this situation where the technology is constantly changing and hence the advice may have to be adjusted.

In a culmination of some two years work in this area, the Archives in November last year hosted a major conference bringing together archivists, record managers, librarians, other information professionals and computer industry personnel to review the state of knowledge about preservation of electronic records and to develop some consensus of approach. The conference was widely attended from Australia and overseas. In recognition of the expertise of the specialists from the Archives acknowledged at the conference, it is now represented on the electronic records committee of the International Council on Archives.

I mentioned at the outset that the Australian Archives has put increasing emphasis on public programs in recent years. Over the last three years, it has mounted a range of exhibitions drawn from items in its collections which both inform and challenge our knowledge and memory of past evidence. A highlight of this exhibition program has been the exhibition `Between Two Worlds', which explores the experiences of people of part-Aboriginal descent who were taken away from their families earlier this century. The exhibition opened at Sydney in October 1993 and has been at a number of venues across the country since then. The exhibition is currently in Western Australia and is scheduled to open in Dubbo in May.

Other significant exhibitions that have been staged in Old Parliament House include `Making Ends Meet', which is about the development of child endowment for Australian families, and an exhibition on `Trademarks' as part of Australia's cultural identify.

To mark the 50th anniversary of the death of John Curtin, the Archives is staging an exhibition on Curtin's life, which will open in this building later this year. The exhibition is being developed in conjunction with the Curtin Foundation and will eventually reside permanently at the Curtin Centre in Perth.

The importance of exhibitions is the opportunity they provide to reach a much wider number of Australians. The greater majority of us will never become researchers in the search rooms of the Australian Archives but, through exhibitions, the Archives is able to reach a much wider audience to enable people to be informed about aspects of Australia's history and development.

Another project the Archives has commenced is the production of the first comprehensive guide to the records relating to the development of the constitution and federation in Australia. The Archives sees this as its major contribution to the centenary of federation. Its intention is that the guide be completed and published well ahead of 2001 so it will be available as a source for others writing about and preparing education kits and exhibitions on federation. This guide will build upon a series of published guides the Archives has already published in recent years, such as those describing records relating to genealogical research, to lighthouses and to Aboriginal Australians.

It is appropriate at this stage to look at the future environment for the Archives. The Australian Archives has identified a number of challenges it needs to address over the coming decade. These are: challenges in the changing nature of records and their use in government—and I have already referred to the issue of electronic records in this context; challenges in increasing users' appreciation of the records in the Archives' custody and access to them; challenges in arresting the deterioration of records in custody.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Snow)—Order! Will members please subdue their conversations.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Archives' strategies in response to these challenges are: to improve the value of records to government and the community but establish standards for documentation; to direct resources increasingly towards the identification, control, preservation and acceptability of records of enduring value; and to promote wider acceptability and use of the archival resources of Australia.

PARA.TAB: The Archives is pursuing these strategies vigorously. I have already referred to some of the achievements. It is also conscious of the need to work cooperatively with other cultural institutions and seeks to do so wherever possible. In meeting the challenges it has identified, the Archives is changing from a low profile backroom agency, which was principally a warehouse for government records that had ceased to be of administrative use, to a modern archival institution which seeks to employ best practices in its facilities, in its handling of records and in making them available to the public.

I referred earlier to the access arrangements the Archives has developed. Under the Archives Act, there is a general presumption that government records will be available for public scrutiny after 30 years as a right. The task of ensuring that records are available to the public at 30 years has always been a challenge to the Archives. Honourable members will be aware that the 30-year-old cabinet records are made available each new year and there is a growing media interest in them. Indeed, a straightforward comparison of the 1994 and 1995 openings of 1963 and 1964 cabinet papers reveals the realisation that there is a records superhighway worth exploring. The press coverage this year, whether measured in terms of editorials, letters to the editor, number of articles or column inches, more than doubled over the last year.

Given the need to examine records for material that might need to remain exempt after 30 years, it has not always been possible for other 30-year-old material to be so readily available. Increased efforts by the Archives in this area and the development of new approaches in the light of experience are now enabling the Archives to ensure to a much greater extent that records will be readily available when sought. Obviously, the resource costs of preserving and making records available are significant. In Australia and in other Western democracies this has always been seen as a legitimate expenditure in the public interest.

It is significant that through better management the Archives has been able to handle rapidly increasing numbers of public inquiries without seeking additional resources externally. By way of example, in 1989-90 visits to the search room by members of the public totalled 7,500. By 1993-94 this had almost doubled to 13,500. Over the same five-year period, the number of new researchers registering with the Archives each year increased from 2,145 in 1989-90 to 3,284 in 1993-94. Other statistics reveal a similar growth.

One thing the Archives lacks is a significant national building in order to focus its presence. The Advisory Council on Australian Archives has, since its inception, identified the lack of a national building as the outstanding requirement to enable the Archives to take its rightful place amongst the significant cultural institutions of this nation. There have been plans and proposals for a national archives building since this national capital was first developed. To date, none of them have come to fruition. Because of its unique position as a central support to government administration, as well as being a significant cultural institution holding much of the information about Australia's development, I believe that now is the time to decide that the Archives deserves a permanent location within the national capital's central areas. I know that the Archives has indicated that part of the building presently occupied by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade—the administrative building—would provide a suitable national headquarters. It would seem to be too good an opportunity to miss and would avoid the need for a substantial capital outlay on a new building. Only when it is appropriately located does the council believe that the Archives will have the opportunity to perform its role to the greatest effect.

I have spoken at some length about the Australian Archives—but I did follow some people speaking about a legal bill—because it is an important institution and it receives too little attention in this place. Let me conclude by saying that the evidence is on the record that the Australian Archives has substantial achievements to its credit. It is focused in its approach and has a clear view and strategy for the next decade. It is aware of the challenges that confront a modern archives and is meeting these challenges. If it achieves its goals, we can confidently expect that the Australian Archives, at the turn of the century, will be a vital national organisation assisting good administration and accountability in government and making a valuable contribution to understanding our past and how our society has evolved.

As I said at the outset, along with Senator Margaret Reid I serve on the Advisory Council on Australian Archives. I think we are the longest serving members, having served on the council for approximately 10 years, and we hope that we make a significant contribution. I appeal to my parliamentary colleagues, especially ministers, parliamentary secretaries and chairpersons of caucus, in saying that the Labor Party caucus records should be in the Australian Archives, not in the National Library. I appeal to honourable members to investigate with Australian Archives the possibility of storing your office correspondence so that future generations and future researchers can study that documentation and see what a wise and able group of people occupied this building in this year. I urge you to investigate with Australian Archives the possibility of recording and storing your material there. At least it enables you to clear out your office.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate those final comments, and I agree that it is important that those documents be stored with Australian Archives.
—Those that have not been shredded.
—Those which have not been shredded could be entered on a LCD screen so that they could be changed at any time to suit whatever particular person happens to be the leader at the time.

PARA.TAB: In starting my contribution to the debate on the Archives Amendment Bill, I refer to my favourite author, George Orwell, whose magnum opus is Nineteen Eighty-four. Some honourable members—particularly those honourable members who saw the very good film which was made of the book Nineteen Eighty-four starring Richard Burton and John Hurt—may recall the role played by Winston Smith. Winston Smith, of course, played the role of the antihero of the novel and he had a function to perform in the ministry of truth. In the book, the ministry of truth deals with lies, similar to the ministry of plenty, which deals with shortages, and the ministry of peace, with deals with wars. The ministry of truth and the ministry of plenty are similar to the ministry of employment in the Labor government which predominantly deals with unemployment.

In Winston Smith's role in the ministry of truth, his job was to update back copies of the Times newspaper and to alter them in such a way as to reflect more positively on the regime, the Ingsoc, the ruling English socialist party of Oceana, or Landstrip 1, as the United Kingdom was termed in the novel. There is a particular maxim that is used in the ministry of truth by Ingsoc, and that is `He who controls the present controls the past, and he who controls the past controls the future.'

Those who saw that particularly well-made film and who can recall the images of John Hurt as Winston Smith sitting there, sending down the old versions of the Times newspaper into the vast furnace that was, presumably, on the bottom floor or in the basement of this large pyramid shaped building, can understand how an ability to control the past and to be able to alter history places the present incumbents in a very powerful position indeed. In order for us to be able to interpret history, in order for us to be able to interpret the present and to look towards the future, we require records, documents and those valuable oral histories which are being compiled this year as part of the Australia Remembers commemoration.

These sorts of items and government records are invaluable for citizens to be able to determine exactly how the present situation came to pass and what has occurred in the past. When one looks at recent history—in particular, in my state, the state of Western Australia—under the previous Labor governments of Brian Burke, Peter Dowding and, of course, Carmen Lawrence, one of the most serious criticisms by the royal commission that was conducted into the affairs of Western Australia Inc. was that many documents and other records of ministers and cabinet were discovered to be missing. This situation meant that it was very difficult for the royal commissioners to be able to determine precisely what had occurred. In fact, on a number of occasions—

TALK.START.PARA: —What has this got to do with the bill?

—The parliamentary secretary asked, `What has this got to do with the bill?' If the parliamentary secretary had listened to my opening remarks, he would see how it is relevant. Particularly in the case of the records of cabinet—which are very important records in any government system—there were occurrences where evidence of the missing records was the fact that there were yellow tabs still stuck in the files where those records ought to have been. It was as though somebody had left the yellow tabs in place in case they needed to put the missing records back in the right place.

PARA.TAB: The Archives Amendment Bill is a bill which makes amendments in minor policy. Nonetheless, the amendments are important because they impact on our principal source of national records, Australian Archives, which was established by the Archives Act in 1983. I listened with great interest yesterday to the statement by the Speaker of the House of Representatives in relation to access to other important databases, such as those which are held by the Parliamentary Library, and, most particularly, the Hansard records of parliamentary debates.

The Speaker made quite positive and progressive comments about the accessibility of those records to the community. In fact, via the Internet, that incredible expanding communication network that Australians can have access to at a relatively cheap cost, people will soon be able to go into the Hansard records and be able to conduct searches in the records, such as we are able to do in our own personal computers which are on-line with the Parliamentary Library.

This is a very significant and important democratic influence because, quite clearly, in any vibrant and healthy democracy, access to information, particularly the records of decision-makers, of particular public officials, is critical. That is why any movement to make those records more accessible to the community is to be commended.

The Australian Archives is responsible for the management of records, including the storage, transfer and custody of those records. The bill arises from issues in relation to ownership of some of these records, particularly from previous government departments that have been privatised, corporatised or in some other changed in a way that may mean that those records become unavailable or less available to the Australian Archives and to the community. The bill arises from the inadvertent loss of ownership over pre-incorporation records of organisations such as the Commonwealth Bank, the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, the International Wool Commission and the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation.

But I would like to point out that, while the ramifications of this bill do not impact greatly on the man or woman in the street, there is at the heart of this matter the general principle of access to information of all kinds in this country, particularly that information that is contained within the numerous government archives.

I raised the question of Western Australia Inc. because that was, within recent memory, a good example of how records that are critical to the public interest can be lost or spirited away in such a way that the commissioners of the WA Inc. royal commission were deprived of the opportunity to verify the truth of the matter in relation to the issues that they had undertaken to examine or investigate. It made for less efficient royal commission findings: because of the lack of particular documents, the commissioners were unable to reach conclusions on a number of matters. That is one of the reasons why I, and members of the opposition, have a great deal of interest in the workings of the Australian Archives, as do the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) and Senator Reid of the Australian Capital Territory, both of whom are on the board. I commend their work in ensuring that the Archives do reflect the intent to provide accessible information for Australian citizens.

I can tell you, speaking from the perspective of Western Australians who live on the other side of the continent, that access to the Archives in a number of cases has become a matter of some concern. In particular, I refer to a gentleman by the name of Mr Funch of Roleystone, in the hills of the metropolitan area. He is an historian who finds his research all but impossible now that the government has indicated he must fully pay for his research projects. Formerly, he was able to have the assistance of staff at the Australian Archives to assist him with various projects. We find that, as a consequence of those charges, historians like Mr Funch and others who reside in Western Australia or, for that matter, in other more remote states find themselves at a considerable disadvantage, compared with those who may reside within travelling distance of the archive.

I might also at the same time refer to another important Australian institution, the War Memorial, which is another source of records invaluable to historians who are endeavouring to write about Australia's past. In many cases these are people who are writing about histories that are perhaps less significant in terms of the national stage, but significant in terms of regional local interests: histories of some importance to local people or to people who reside in a particular area.

Jim Davies is another historian who resides in my electorate who has written a number of popular books about Australia's involvement in World War II. One book, The Lady was not a Spy, detailed in anecdotal form the adventures of Army and other service personnel along the Western Australian coast during the Second World War. Although it is not strictly relevant to the Australian Archives, it is following down the same issue. Both Mr Funch and Mr Davies, in their respective interests in obtaining information, have had difficulty in being able to get the information, because both the Archives and the War Memorial have stopped doing research for local authors. That has severely affected Mr Funch's ability to be able to write his local history and, in the case of Mr Davies, to write a follow-up book to The Lady was not a Spy which deals with wartime experiences of people in Western Australia.

I have made a number of representations on behalf of both of these particular people. In the case of Mr Davies—and, of course, he also wished to avail himself of information in the Australian Archives—he must now pay a professional researcher up to $40 an hour to attend the War Memorial or the Australian Archives to be able to avail himself of that information. Obviously in the case of a state like Western Australia—and, I am sure, in the case of the home state of the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan)—that is a severe financial impediment. The travelling costs and the accommodation are so prohibitive that unless historians are writing things that are going to be huge best-sellers, they could not possibly afford to travel to the national capital to undertake their own research. In my view, Mr Deputy Speaker, this is flying in the face of the stated policy of the government to make these types of records more readily available for the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —They're very expensive. It's a very expensive exercise.

—I understand they are very expensive. Nonetheless, in a federation the size of Australia the interests of all Australians, not just those that live within reasonable motoring distance of here, ought to be regarded. They ought to be given the opportunity to avail themselves of this information without prohibitive costs.

PARA.TAB: On behalf of these two historians I have written to the various ministers to elicit a more favourable response for them. Unfortunately, the best they could say was that in the case of the War Memorial there is a research fund, and that the Australian Archives can provide access to the actual indexes of information. But these people would have to avail themselves of a researcher to pull out those particular documents and look at them and do whatever necessary research is involved. As I said earlier, that is a severe impediment to the writing of local histories in my home state.

The minister tells me that most of the information is available at state archive departments at 30c a page. He also informs me that, in the case of the War Memorial, all books held in the research centre are listed on the Australian Bibliographic Network, available at larger state libraries. The War Memorial in particular has limited research grants available, but these are all but useless to writers of small histories such as Mr Funch and Mr Davies. They are forced to rely on the goodwill and assistance of government departments, and it seems that in the case of the federal government this goodwill is drying up. In the name of user pays, we see that in the case of outlying states—the more remote states—people are unable to get that access.

Finally, Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like to refer to the matter concerning to the arrangements in relation to the Australian Archives and the national witness protection plan. The Parliamentary Secretary (Mr Lindsay) was pointing at me a minute ago. He and I used to be on the Joint Standing Committee on the National Crime Authority together, and he would know that in the case of the national witness protection plan there are very, very significant confidentiality and secrecy requirements. Under normal circumstances I would have to agree entirely with the provisions that are in the bill to provide for exemption for Australian Federal Police documents relating to the NWPP. However, the difficulty is that that does tend to make for a less accountable situation in the case of the AFP. I would prefer to see a situation where there were provisions for a more secret arrangement within the Archives for those types of documents.

Clearly, nobody would like to endanger protected witnesses by having their records available to all and sundry, but I would like to see that there is proper accountability and scrutiny of the AFP and, in particular, the NWPP. As a consequence, I would prefer to see a situation where the exemption is not just at the behest of the Australian Federal Police Commissioner but is by mutual arrangement between the Director-General of Archives and the Australian Federal Police Commissioner, where the substantial concerns of public interest are taken into account and where, when necessary, extra secure arrangements can be made for those types of records within the Archives itself.

As I said at the beginning, this is a non-controversial or, let us say, a minor policy change in relation to the Archives. I would like to reiterate the theme of my speech: in the interests of greater accountability, in the interests of a fairer democratic system in our nation, in the interests of those people who live in the outlying states, I urge the honourable member responsible for guiding this legislation through the committee on behalf of the government to reconsider the arrangements in the Archives for people from my state and other outlying states to be able to access historical documents, to make access more fair and equitable to all concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two matters I wish to mention in respect of the Archives Amendment Bill. The first relates to the national witness protection program, which the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) has just mentioned; the second is the contemplation by the bill of legislation by regulation. The Archives Act 1983 established the Australian Archives, which is responsible for the management of Commonwealth records, including the transfer of custody or ownership of those records.

PARA.TAB: This bill has been prompted by the need to ensure that the Archives Act applies to the pre-incorporation records of such bodies as government business enterprises which have since establishment been commercialised, incorporated or privatised. Under the current law, there is nothing to prevent such bodies from inadvertently or deliberately removing their pre-incorporation records from the Australian Archives. This defect in the law has resulted in the pre-incorporation records of bodies such as the Commonwealth Bank, the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, the International Wool Commission and the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation being lost to the Australian Archives.

The Australian Federal Police is a Commonwealth statutory authority established by the Australian Federal Police Act 1979 and, as such, would come within the purview of the Archives Act. But it is important, in the interests of protecting witnesses who are part of the national witness protection program and of preserving the integrity of that program generally, that certain sources and classes of information in the hands of the AFP not be publicly disclosed.

The bill, therefore, exempts from the application of the Archives Act 1983 sensitive records concerning witnesses and participants who are connected with the witness protection program. The exemption is not to apply to such non-sensitive documents as those relating to administrative or budgetary matters, where those documents would not reveal information concerning a witness or a person assessed for inclusion in the program.

As I have said, this is clearly important to the integrity of the program. There is no point in establishing an elaborate and secure scheme for creating, bestowing and protecting a new identity for a witness if the records relating to that scheme are as accessible as those of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. On the other hand, I support the call by the honourable member for Moore for some form of accountability. It is difficult to see how this might be done conveniently but perhaps something in the nature of a prison governor sworn to secrecy who can make regular inspections or audits would be appropriate.

The second matter to which I refer is a matter of concern. Proposed section 3A provides that a body that was established for a public purpose is deemed for the purposes of the Archives Act never to have been so established if either a legislative provision or regulations made for the purposes of the proposed section 3A expressly provide that the body is to be taken never to have been so established. I share the concern of the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee in relation to this provision. The effect of section 3A is that regulations as well as primary legislation can deem a body not to have been established for a public purpose. The ultimate effect of that is that such a body will fall outside the scope of the Archives Act. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee has commented that this may be regarded as `an inappropriate delegation of legislative power'. The committee has sought the minister's advice on whether it might not be more appropriate to achieve this purpose by amending the primary legislation, the Archives Act, instead of the use in this way of the power to make regulations. To date I am not aware that the minister has made a satisfactory or, indeed, any response to the committee's concern.

On other occasions I have referred to my concerns about this government's use of regulations to bypass parliament. We must be vigilant to ensure that the parliament's role is not subverted by delegating the proper work of the parliament to the government to do behind closed doors. This is what happens when legislation is taken out of the hands of the parliament and appropriated by a department in the form of statutory regulations.

Parliament's role is important, not so that we as parliamentarians may have something to do with our time, but because we, the members of parliament, are the representatives of the people and, as such, are a crucial part of the democratic process. Our participation should be observable by the public to whom we are accountable.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LINDSAY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank all honourable members who have made a contribution to the debate on the Archives Amendment Bill, in particular the member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), the member for Moore (Mr Filing) and the member for Tangney (Mr Williams). In response to some of the comments made by the member for Moore, I wish to place on the record that Australian Archives charges for the provision of photocopies of records. It does not charge for access to records by those who are able to visit the search rooms of Archives. However, Archives does have standards of service for customers beyond which it does not have the resources to proceed. Hence, if a researcher requires extensive research to be done and cannot visit the Archives, that person will have to engage the services of a professional researcher.

PARA.TAB: Accordingly, that presents a problem to Australian Archives to provide a service of the kind that is sought by the member for Moore. One remedy Archives is examining is to microfilm the most important records so that copies can be made available in all offices of Archives and in some cases in public libraries. Nevertheless, the holdings of Archives are so vast that it can only ever hope to microfilm a small proportion of them.

In relation to the matter raised by the member for Tangney with respect to the implications of proposed new section 3A, I respond by saying that this matter has been discussed with the Secretary of the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee. The point that the committee has made is clearly appreciated. Nevertheless, the power of regulation was inserted at the suggestion of the Attorney-General's Department. It is thought that this is the appropriate way to proceed. In so far as this method of procedure is concerned, the committee has been, or will be, advised that the power of regulation will be used judiciously and will not be used capriciously. I am sure that the member for Tangney is assured by that solemn undertaking by Australian Archives, given his extensive and eminent legal background.

Mr Deputy Speaker, it is nearly 1 o'clock. I had intended to make some remarks on the necessity for Australian Archives to develop new policies that deal with the retention of electronic information, particularly electronic information held by computers within government service and also within government business enterprises. Unfortunately, time does not permit those remarks to be made. Therefore, I commend the bill to the committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Mr Lindsay)—by leave—agreed to:
That the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 7 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the Government acknowledge the need for persons suffering from chronic fatigue syndrome to obtain appropriate treatment for their condition.
(2) Will the Government provide Medicare rebates to patients seeking treatment for chronic fatigue syndrome.
(3) Did the former Minister for Health, Senator Graham Richardson, enter into an agreement with Dr A. Martinovic on 19 May 1993 to establish a Chronic Fatigue Syndrome Review Committee.

(4) Did the committee's terms of reference include the establishment of a clear set of guidelines to indicate the generally accepted treatment within the Medicare program for chronic fatigue syndrome; if so, what progress has been made towards the establishment of the guidelines.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) Yes—provided that the service or services for which Medicare rebates are being sought are medical services rendered by or on behalf of a medical practitioner and are "clinically relevant". A clinically relevant service means a service rendered by a medical practitioner that is generally accepted in the medical profession as being necessary for the appropriate treatment of the patient to whom it is rendered.

(3) and (4) No. On 19 May 1993, the former Minister offered Dr Martinovic an independent review of his practice in relation to CFS by a special committee established under the National Health Act. Dr Martinovic accepted the offer.
The Chronic Fatigue Syndrome Review Committee's Terms of Reference were to:
(a) review the clinical aspects of the practice of Dr Andriya Martinovic and make recommendations to the Minister for Health concerning—

(i) whether the services rendered by Dr Martinovic for patients suffering from Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS) are of a kind that are generally accepted by the medical profession as appropriate and necessary for the treatment of CFS; and
(ii) whether the frequency of the services/tests rendered or requested by Dr Martinovic is appropriate for the treatment of individual CFS patients.

(b) having regard to current medical practice in Australia, make recommendations to the Minister of Health on diagnostic and management regimes that the medical profession would regard as appropriate for sufferers of CFS.

In its May 1994 Report, the Chronic Fatigue Syndrome Review Committee highlighted the absence of any agreed position on the diagnosis and management of CFS within the Australian health care community. To address this deficiency, it recommended bringing together interested parties from the health care and research communities, government and the general public to develop a consensus on CFS relevant to Australia with strategies for care, research and funding.

Discussions have been held with the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners to conduct a comprehensive survey of the attitudes, beliefs and practices of general practitioners as to the diagnosis and management of CFS. The information obtained from this survey will provide the base from which strategies for the diagnosis and treatment of this debilitating condition can be developed.
